adjective.description: (of lines, planes, surfaces, or objects) side by side and having the same distance continuously between them.
examples: the road runs parallel to the Ottawa River

noun.description: A person or thing that is similar or analogous to another.
examples: a challenge that has no parallel in peacetime this century

noun.description: Each of the imaginary parallel circles of constant latitude on the earth's surface.
Two parallel lines (‖) as a reference mark.

verb.description: (of something extending in a line) be side by side with (something extending in a line), always keeping the same distance.
examples: a big concrete gutter that paralleled the road

phrases: Mass media and popular culture developed in parallel to the Jazz Age in the West.
There are a number of special insights developed in parallel to the main analysis.
In the examples so far discussed, the analysis of a word into its component morphemes takes place in parallel at the phonological and the semantic levels.
It can more easily afford to develop next-generation plant in parallel with older lines.
Thus, it seems that an altered respiratory function develops in parallel with duration of cold exposure.
origin: Mid 16th century: from French parallèle, via Latin from Greek parallēlos, from para- alongside + allēlos one another.
